Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Adding nuget.server package to blank project seems to mangle binding redirects" (#5125) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I created a new empty asp project, added the package nuget.server 3.0.1, updated all other packages and now my web.config seems to have duplicate binding redirects. 

  <runtime>
    <assemblyBinding xmlns="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:asm.v1">
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Diagnostics.DiagnosticSource" publicKeyToken="cc7b13ffcd2ddd51" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-4.0.2.1" newVersion="4.0.2.1" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="Newtonsoft.Json" publicKeyToken="30ad4fe6b2a6aeed" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-9.0.0.0" newVersion="9.0.0.0" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Http" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.2.3.0" newVersion="5.2.3.0" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Formatting" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="Microsoft.Data.Edm" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.7.0.0" newVersion="5.7.0.0" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="Microsoft.Data.OData" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Spatial" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Newtonsoft.Json" publicKeyToken="30ad4fe6b2a6aeed" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-10.0.0.0" newVersion="10.0.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Web.Http" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.2.3.0" newVersion="5.2.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Net.Http.Formatting" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.2.3.0" newVersion="5.2.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Microsoft.Data.Edm" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.8.3.0" newVersion="5.8.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="Microsoft.Data.OData" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.8.3.0" newVersion="5.8.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Spatial" publicKeyToken="31bf3856ad364e35" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-5.8.3.0" newVersion="5.8.3.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
    </assemblyBinding>
  </runtime>

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve unit testing of scenarios checking permissions" (#5124) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We must improve our unit testing such that we test that every action can only be done by expected users.

These possible users include:
1 - Logged out
2 - Unrelated user (not owner of package)
3 - Owner (of package)
4 - Organization Admin
5 - Organization Collaborator
6 - Site Admin

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Issue of managing NuGet package" (#6255) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@Samuel98005 commented on [Mon Dec 04 2017](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5117)


Hi,

I have an issue of managing NuGet package. Basically I tried to resolve this issue with a new Visual Studio installation after uninstalling the existing one. This happens in both Visual Studio 2015 Professional and Enterprise edition in Windows Server 2012. 

The error message I have encountered: "Solution is not saved. Please save your solution before managing NuGet packages."
 
Could someone please help on this?

Kind regards,
Samuel

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Installing EF Core 1.0 into ASP.NET 4 app produces incorrect binding redirect version" (#3274) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
EF Core 1.0 uses System.Collections.Immuable/1.2.0. When installed into a nuget2 project (packages.config), the wrong binding redirect version is created.
## Repro

File -> New Project... -> ASP.NET 4 WebAPI
Install-Package Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore -Version 1.0.0
## Expected result

web.config should contain

``` xml
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Collections.Immutable" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.2.0.0" newVersion="1.2.0.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
```
## Actual result

web.config contains

``` xml
      <dependentAssembly>
        <assemblyIdentity name="System.Collections.Immutable" publicKeyToken="b03f5f7f11d50a3a" culture="neutral" />
        <bindingRedirect oldVersion="0.0.0.0-1.1.36.0" newVersion="1.1.36.0" />
      </dependentAssembly>
```
## Setup info

VS 2015 Update 3
NuGet Package Manager 3.5.0.1484

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Tools as a project reference" (#2469) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently, tools extensions can only be added as a package reference. This makes local development of tools and end to end testing cumbersome.
## Example scenario

Be able to reference a dotnet tool from a project in the same solution.

```
src/
     dotnet-ef
test/
     testProject/
          project.json <-- references dotnet-ef as a tool
```

``` json
{
    "tools": {
         "dotnet-ef": { "target": "project" }
    }
}
```
## Workaround

In the meantime, the inner dev cycle is to pack and restore the tool into the test project.

Events.RelatedBody: Due to a logic bug, the default hash algorithm is always SHA-2-256.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "mssign command doesn't produce same logging as sign command" (#6263) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The sign command prints out some info like the following:

```
Signing package(s) with certificate:
Subject Name: CN=My self-signed certificate
SHA1 hash: D1AF2DCCB45FEFCECC5CEC3D38D4C794BC074CA4
Issued by: CN=My self-signed certificate
Valid from: 11/1/2017 1:00:00 AM to 11/1/2020 1:00:00 AM

Timestamping package(s) with:
<URL hidden>

Package(s) signed successfully.
```

The msssign command only prints:

    Package(s) signed successfully.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "HashAlgorithm hard-coded to default" (#6262) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Due to a logic bug, the default hash algorithm is always SHA-2-256.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "API Question: How can custom HTTP headers be added to request?" (#6238) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Version Nuget.* 4.x.x

I'm building a automated application update process that will rely on using a Nuget feed.  Our internal Nuget Server (ProGet) supports several custom HTTP Headers.  These headers can be used to send the username, date, application, etc.

How can I add these headers to at least the DownloadResource::GetResourceAsync() call?

Thanks

-marc

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Limit maximum package cache size" (#6261) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
My organization is a heavy user of NuGet for distributing pre-built C++ & .NET libraries. This works very well, but we sometime struggle with the package cache growing to unreasonable sizes (>100GB) over time. This is causing problems for CI nodes and laptop users with limited disk sizes.

More specifically, we're observing that the `C:\Users\user\.nuget\packages\` folder contains both the nupkg as well as unzipped version of all versions of all nuget packages ever downloaded for a given user. This does not scale very well for users downloading >100MB of new nuget packages every week.

Would it be possible to implement some sort of "maximum cache size" parameter that can be used to limit the maximum amount of disk space used for nuget caching?
Alternatively, a "maximum package version" parameter to limit the number of versions cached for a given package?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
